quotes.text: The use of the word beauty in books that have been digitized by Google has decreased, like pretty dramatically.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete cultural/data signal that “beauty” is being deprioritized, setting up why teams may need to reassert its value.

quotes.topic_title: Beauty enhances functionality and builds trust
quotes.text: As if people think about functionality and beauty as like two opposite things. No, they're not two opposite things.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that challenges the common tradeoff mindset and invites practitioners to design for both simultaneously.

quotes.topic_title: Beauty enhances functionality and builds trust
quotes.text: And actually beauty enhances functionality because it does make things easier to use, more approachable, more compelling to use.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Provides an actionable mental model: treat beauty as a usability lever that improves approachability and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Beauty enhances functionality and builds trust
quotes.text: Things that are more beautiful, increase trust.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A practical principle for product teams: visual polish can directly affect perceived credibility and user confidence.

quotes.topic_title: Beauty enhances functionality and builds trust
quotes.text: You see that we've put painstaking detail into this, and we care about the details of how something works, and that gives you assurance that we care about other details that you can't see too.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism behind trust: visible care signals invisible care, guiding where to invest in craft and detail.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She's built and led design teams at three different hypergrowth companies, seen the teams scale at least 10x, and two of which, Airbnb and Stripe, are some of the biggest and fastest growing companies in the world and also the best designed products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights concrete hypergrowth experience (10x scaling) and ties design leadership to outcomes at top-tier companies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation Katie shares stories of trials and tribulations of leading large design teams, processes she's put in place for operationalizing quality, how she thinks about quality and beauty very practically, how design can directly lead to growth, and examples of this that led to a big lift in conversion at Stripe, plus a math formula she uses to increase team performance, how she suggests organizing your design and product teams, what to look for in design hires, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews multiple actionable levers—operationalizing quality, linking design to growth, a performance formula, org design, and hiring criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career, and something that worked really well for me a few years ago, is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a specific, replicable career tactic: form a “personal board of directors” for ongoing feedback and decision support.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career, and something that worked really well for me a few years ago, is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.

quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mechanism for getting higher-quality feedback—structured peer groups designed for candor and perspective diversity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges the assumption that building a trusted network must take many years.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Jira Product Discovery you can gather all your product ideas and insights in one place and prioritize confidently, finally replacing those endless spreadsheets.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable product-ops advice: centralize ideas/insights to improve prioritization and reduce spreadsheet-driven process overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Great products are built by great teams, not just engineers.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable principle emphasizing cross-functional contribution as a core ingredient of product success.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team intervention and trust lesson
quotes.text: So whether how right or how wrong what I was doing was, is the key piece is that I wasn't bringing the team along with me.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights a leadership mental model: correctness matters less than enrolling the team in the change.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team intervention and trust lesson
quotes.text: You can inflict change on people, but if you want to do it with them trust is the key element there.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A memorable, actionable distinction between forcing change and co-creating it, with trust as the lever.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team intervention and trust lesson
quotes.text: And then a couple months later, we had the best engagement scores in the company.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Concrete outcome showing that shifting to trust-building and inclusion can measurably improve engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team intervention and trust lesson
quotes.text: And just think about instead of coming in swinging, come in listening, so that you can really set out to make change that actually has true, positive impact on the folks around you and that you bring along with you.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Practical advice for new leaders: lead with listening to build trust and increase the odds change sticks.

quotes.topic_title: Org design: sitting together and dual identity
quotes.text: And one of the things that I believe as a necessary part of building a high-functioning organization is that, one, building together is important.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A clear org-design principle: co-locate cross-functional partners to increase alignment and execution quality.

quotes.topic_title: Org design: sitting together and dual identity
quotes.text: So having engineers, and product managers, and designers be together, have shared goals, and align on that and be able to just look over each other's shoulder and talk about things, is important.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how proximity supports shared goals, fast feedback, and day-to-day collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Org design: sitting together and dual identity
quotes.text: However, that Thayer thing that you're talking about actually was like something that I was very devoted to, which is bringing Design together at key moments multiple times throughout the week to also build a community in Design.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A practical operating cadence: even when embedded, designers need recurring rituals to maintain a strong craft community.

quotes.topic_title: Org design: sitting together and dual identity
quotes.text: And I was like, "You have two T-shirts. You have the Design T-shirt and you have the Marketplace T-shirt, or whatever cross-disciplinary team that you work on. Because both are really important communities to build for slightly different reasons."
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for dual identity—belonging to both the design org and the product team—to get the benefits of each.

quotes.topic_title: Making the ROI case for design quality
quotes.text: But I think first to kind of level set before we dive into that I would say that there are levels of quality. There is the, does the thing work? Does it provide some sort of value proposition? It like executes on its job. That's baseline quality.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Introduces a practical “levels of quality” framework teams can use to calibrate what “quality” means before debating ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Making the ROI case for design quality
quotes.text: But the companies that know that quality is non-negotiable, it is a long-term necessary aspect of what they build, don't play that numbers game. Or what they do is they recognize that it is absolutely functionality, but the quality of those features that is actually going to get to great usability, desirability in their product.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Challenges the default “only prioritize what you can measure” approach and reframes quality as essential to usability and desirability.

quotes.topic_title: Making the ROI case for design quality
quotes.text: Lastly, I'll just say that I know there's this saying of it's growth versus quality, but quality is growth.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that helps leaders justify investing in design quality as a growth lever, not a tradeoff.

quotes.topic_title: Making the ROI case for design quality
quotes.text: In fact, at Stripe our Growth team I would say is pretty much maniacally focused on building better experiences because we've seen it tied directly to our business metrics.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Shows an operational model: Growth teams can focus on experience quality because it can be directly linked to business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Making the ROI case for design quality
quotes.text: So by improving the quality of the checkout experience through details small and large, we have seen a 10.5% increase in business' revenue from an older form of checkout to a newer form of checkout.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A concrete data point demonstrating that design/UX quality improvements can produce material revenue lift.

quotes.topic_title: Design goals vs business goals is a false split
quotes.text: Honestly, a pet peeve of mine is this way of talking about things as there's business goals and there's design goals. Because I think maybe the first conversation one should have is that, "What are we trying to build towards?"
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Reframes the common design-vs-business tension into an alignment question that teams can use to set shared direction.

quotes.topic_title: Design goals vs business goals is a false split
quotes.text: So this is, again, why I was talking about how important it is to have multidisciplinary teams that work closely together because sometimes we are the checks and balances in the conversation.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Actionable team-structure guidance: use cross-functional collaboration to prevent one-dimensional optimization (e.g., metric hacks).

quotes.topic_title: Design goals vs business goals is a false split
quotes.text: But I do think if we can align on what are we trying to build? Are we trying to build something great, then we can recognize the fact that it isn't just that utility is an incredible important part of that, but so is usability and so is desirability because these things together make something truly great.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Provides a practical framework for “great” products as the combination of utility, usability, and desirability.

quotes.topic_title: Design goals vs business goals is a false split
quotes.text: I think that beauty on its own or just craft on its own without utility, I mean that's like, I don't know, that's like Blu-ray or PATH. Right? That does not lead to a high-quality product.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Memorable counterexample that warns against prioritizing craft/beauty without clear utility.

quotes.topic_title: Design goals vs business goals is a false split
quotes.text: taking it to that next level and thinking about, "How do I make this actually an enjoyable use and that it really feels like it's meant for me and it maps my mental model," that craft and that quality of the execution of those details is going to be paramount.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Concrete design lens: optimize for enjoyment and mental-model fit, not just conversion mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Defining beauty: trust, emotion, and pride
quotes.text: Functionality is important, and actually beauty enhances functionality because it does make things easier to use, more approachable, more compelling to use.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Reframes “beauty vs. function” as a false tradeoff and gives a practical reason to invest in aesthetics: it improves usability and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Defining beauty: trust, emotion, and pride
quotes.text: they studied the tweets that came from people that were traveling through Penn Station versus Grand Central.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Offers a concrete, research-backed example of measuring how environments/design influence user sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: Defining beauty: trust, emotion, and pride
quotes.text: the people tweeting from Penn Station, it was just like more negative than the people that were tweeting from Grand Central Station that tended to be much more positive and optimistic.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A memorable comparison showing that design quality can materially shift how people feel and communicate.

quotes.topic_title: Defining beauty: trust, emotion, and pride
quotes.text: Because, number one, things that are more beautiful, increase trust.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Actionable product principle: visual/craft quality can be used as a lever to build user trust, especially in high-stakes domains.

quotes.topic_title: Defining beauty: trust, emotion, and pride
quotes.text: If we put that care into our work, more people will want to work with us, because they want to see their time spent and the care for their craft recognized and utilized and see that that can be put together into something really impactful.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Connects design quality to talent attraction/retention—an operational reason leaders can use to justify investing in craft.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe builds a high-craft website
quotes.text: Because the gravitational pull is to mediocrity.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why quality decays unless teams actively fight for a higher bar.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe builds a high-craft website
quotes.text: It is very easy to fall into a path of a baseline, where what is required to go to that next level where something feels truly great is certainly a lot of effort, and it's a concerted effort.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that “great” requires deliberate, sustained investment beyond default execution.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe builds a high-craft website
quotes.text: we view it as a articulation of how we care about our users in all that we provide for them.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A framing that treats the website as a direct expression of user care, raising the stakes for craft decisions.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe builds a high-craft website
quotes.text: Actually, it's one of the few teams where all of these things report, well, not all of them, but most of those functions report into one place. So, engineering and design actually all report up into the design organization when they work on the website.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A concrete org-design mechanism for operationalizing craft: unify reporting lines to speed iteration and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe builds a high-craft website
quotes.text: So, that rapid cycle of iteration is really, really powerful, especially when we're trying to move quickly, but at an extremely high standard.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights a practical process principle: tight iteration loops enable both speed and high quality simultaneously.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing quality: vision, editing, courage, journeys
quotes.text: Number one is that quality is definitely a group effort. You're sunk if you think that you can just hire some incredibly talented person and they'll do it, that'll be fine. The rest of us will do what we're doing and they'll do it, or that it's just one organization that's going to look out for quality or QA is going to solve it all for you. It really does need to be an organizational and a group effort.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that quality can’t be outsourced to a star hire or a single function; it must be owned across the org.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing quality: vision, editing, courage, journeys
quotes.text: Number two is that there needs to be some amount of vision and alignment. So, if you hire all the best people in the world and you just set them out to go and do their thing, what are the chances that they're all going to end up with something that actually aligns pretty well?
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights alignment as a prerequisite for coherent craft, even with high-taste teams.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing quality: vision, editing, courage, journeys
quotes.text: I think a big pair on that is then the next piece, which is editing.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Names “editing” as a distinct operational lever for quality—beyond vision—focused on narrowing and removing what doesn’t fit.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing quality: vision, editing, courage, journeys
quotes.text: That pairs with the next piece, which is about courage, the ability to actually say, "No, this isn't good enough." To have the resolve to just be like, "Almost, but no."
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Actionable leadership behavior: enforcing standards requires the willingness to stop or redo work even when it’s close.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing quality: vision, editing, courage, journeys
quotes.text: The user very, very, very rarely just deals with any aspect of what you build in isolation.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A journey-based mental model: evaluate quality across the end-to-end user experience, not isolated screens or features.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s “walk the store” essential journeys program
quotes.text: So, our goal was to set out to try to solve the fact that products can be shipped and they could be at their highest game when you ship them, they go through all the processes internally to be a high quality thing, and then it gets out into the world and then, over time, the quality regresses.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights the core problem the program is designed to solve: quality decay after launch despite strong pre-ship processes.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s “walk the store” essential journeys program
quotes.text: What we have established are we started with 15 of our most important user journeys. 15 is somewhat of an arbitrary number. It's a number that we can kind of keep track of, but also has pretty good breadth, but is certainly not comprehensive of all the most important things.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A practical scoping heuristic: pick a manageable set of “essential journeys” that’s trackable even if not exhaustive.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s “walk the store” essential journeys program
quotes.text: They review these journeys, what we call walk the store, where they review them as if they're walking the floor of their store on a regular cadence, and they friction log what they experience, which I know David Singleton talked about on your podcast.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Defines the operational mechanism (“walk the store” + friction logs) leaders can adopt to continuously inspect real user experience.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s “walk the store” essential journeys program
quotes.text: And very critically, it's a journey, so a lot of times it starts from internet search, it starts on Google trying to understand something, goes to the website, they end up on Docs, they end up in the dashboard, and they're seeing it as a user might.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Expands the quality surface area beyond the product UI to the full end-to-end path users actually take.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s “walk the store” essential journeys program
quotes.text: But what we do as managers is we calibrate. We come together and we talk about, "Okay, how well is our interpretation of our ladders document? And how well does that performance align? And are we doing it consistently across the rest of the organization?" So, we do something very similar. We calibrate these scores because what we're really trying to do is not just the 15 essential journeys and the owners of those, we want to actually uplevel and bring more shared understanding of our quality bar across the company.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Introduces a scalable governance model: calibrate quality scoring like performance reviews to align the organization on a shared quality bar.

quotes.topic_title: Cadence, participants, and scoring mechanics
quotes.text: I do think what's so powerful about doing it firsthand is that, although I am the biggest supporter of user research, even hearing somebody talk about an experience, while that is really, really powerful, feeling the pain firsthand is just this next level of visceral understanding of like, "Oh, this could be better."
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Emphasizes a complementary method to research/data: firsthand use creates visceral clarity that can surface issues users won’t articulate.

quotes.topic_title: Cadence, participants, and scoring mechanics
quotes.text: We today are doing it quarterly. The quarterly aspect of walking the stores by no means meant to be like that's the only time people do it. But that is the time where we're looking for update your scorecard and share the information in a dashboard where everybody can see.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Gives an operational cadence model: quarterly formal scoring + dashboard visibility, without limiting informal frequency.

quotes.topic_title: Cadence, participants, and scoring mechanics
quotes.text: At bare minimum, it should be the engineer, product manager and designer doing it together.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Defines a practical minimum cross-functional “trio” to run walkthroughs and capture different quality perspectives.

quotes.topic_title: Cadence, participants, and scoring mechanics
quotes.text: So far we have landed on a color system because, honestly, I think people can get a little tied around the axle on how you're measuring it, and to your point, especially in subjective things, and it's just like, "Oh, it's like, well, is it really a six or is it a seven?" We didn't want people to get a little too worried about how does... It's not meant to be an objective quantitative score. It is qualitative, it is judgment. We hire people for judgment, so we want them to bring that to the conversation.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Explains a scoring mechanic that avoids false precision and reinforces judgment as the core input in qualitative quality reviews.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing quality fixes vs roadmap commitments
quotes.text: We at Stripe think that, first and foremost, is that we have to make sure that folks are, number one, hired with the fact that they have great judgment and care for what they build, and they take pride in it.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A hiring-first approach to quality: prioritize judgment and pride over process rules to ensure quality work happens without constant oversight.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing quality fixes vs roadmap commitments
quotes.text: Then, you can give a lot of trust to people based on that commitment to building great things that they will use that in their decision-making.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Operationalizes quality prioritization by decentralizing decisions—trust teams to make the right tradeoffs when they’re hired for the right traits.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing quality fixes vs roadmap commitments
quotes.text: Then, of course, it needs to be very clearly advocated for at the highest levels of the... Advocated for at the highest levels of the company.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights that culture alone isn’t enough—quality needs explicit top-level advocacy to stay prioritized against roadmap pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing quality fixes vs roadmap commitments
quotes.text: but there is iteration in the plans and we do have multidisciplinary people making the plans together.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: A planning methodology: keep plans iterative and cross-functional so quality improvements can be integrated alongside feature and growth work.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing quality fixes vs roadmap commitments
quotes.text: And so I think that's how we together get to it, but there's no formula that we ask people to.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Contrasts with time-percentage allocation models—Stripe relies on judgment + advocacy + cross-functional planning rather than rigid formulas.
